guide.introduction: When my 3-year-old daughter dropped the $1 battery-powered fan I bought her, the plastic case cracked, ruining it. I promised her I’d make something even better using the fan’s motor. I’m a fan of Chico Bicalho’s wonderful windup toys, so I made a robot inspired by his designs. I call mine the Vibrobot, and you can make one in a couple of hours or less.
guide.introduction_rendered:
When my 3-year-old daughter dropped the $1 battery-powered fan I bought her, the plastic case cracked, ruining it. I promised her I’d make something even better using the fan’s motor. I’m a fan of Chico Bicalho’s wonderful windup toys, so I made a robot inspired by his designs. I call mine the Vibrobot, and you can make one in a couple of hours or less.

Relevant parts
  • Metal candy mint tin
  • Wire Coat Hanger
  • Motor
  • Metal Washer
  • Nuts & Bolts
  • insulated wrapping wire
  • Paper clip
  • Plastic Washer
  • AA Battery
  • Cable Tie
Tools
  • Hammer
  • Hot glue gun
  • Phillips screwdriver
  • Soldering iron
  • Wire cutter/stripper

lines.text: Sand the paint off the tin, if you wish.
lines.text_raw: Sand the paint off the tin, if you wish.

lines.text: Punch 2 holes through the bottom of the tin, one on either end, using a hammer and a Phillips screwdriver. You’ll use these holes to attach the legs.
lines.text_raw: Punch 2 holes through the bottom of the tin, one on either end, using a hammer and a Phillips screwdriver. You’ll use these holes to attach the legs.

lines.text: Punch a hole through the lid near one end. This hole is for routing the wires.
lines.text_raw: Punch a hole through the lid near one end. This hole is for routing the wires.

lines.text: Snip off 2 long pieces of wire from a coat hanger and bend each into a V-shape.
lines.text_raw: Snip off 2 long pieces of wire from a coat hanger and bend each into a V-shape.

lines.text: Bend the tip of the V into a right angle, and then bend a little “foot” at each end.
lines.text_raw: Bend the tip of the V into a right angle, and then bend a little “foot” at each end.

lines.text: Attach the legs to the holes in the tin using bolts, nuts, and metal washers.
lines.text_raw: Attach the legs to the holes in the tin using bolts, nuts, and metal washers.

lines.text: Add a dollop of hot glue to each foot to give them rubber tips.
lines.text_raw: Add a dollop of hot glue to each foot to give them rubber tips.

lines.text: Push a paper clip through one of the plastic flat washers, and attach the washer to the spindle of the motor.
lines.text_raw: Push a paper clip through one of the plastic flat washers, and attach the washer to the spindle of the motor.

lines.text: Solder 2 wires to the 1.5V battery, insert the battery in the candy tin, and thread both wires through the hole in the lid.
lines.text_raw: Solder 2 wires to the 1.5V battery, insert the battery in the candy tin, and thread both wires through the hole in the lid.

lines.text: Solder one wire to a lead on the motor, and solder a third loose wire to the other motor lead.
lines.text_raw: Solder one wire to a lead on the motor, and solder a third loose wire to the other motor lead.

lines.text: Put 2 plastic flat washers between the motor and the candy tin, and secure the motor to the tin using a cable tie.
lines.text_raw: Put 2 plastic flat washers between the motor and the candy tin, and secure the motor to the tin using a cable tie.

lines.text: To operate the Vibrobot, twist the loose battery wire and the loose motor wire together (you can also solder an alligator clip to one of the wires for a switch).
lines.text_raw: To operate the Vibrobot, twist the loose battery wire and the loose motor wire together (you can also solder an alligator clip to one of the wires for a switch).

lines.text: Experiment with the critter by gently bending the paper clip and legs into different shapes and observing the effects.
lines.text_raw: Experiment with the critter by gently bending the paper clip and legs into different shapes and observing the effects.

guide.summary: A simple, fun robot for the rest of us.
